abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery
            Credit will help finance the 2000-01 year slice of the
            National Rehabilitation and Recovery Program in Sierra
            Leone, focused on sustaining peace, and restoring security.
            The operation will be a quick disbursing credit, providing
            the critical balance of payments, and budgetary support to
            partly finance the foreign exchange, and budgetary costs of
            establishing all three dimensions of security, i.e.,
            protective, socioeconomic, and, transparent governance. The
            proceeds will allow the import of essential commodities -
            food, petroleum, and, raw materials - required for
            re-launching the economy. Local currency funds will enable
            the provision of basic services, restoration of law and
            order, and the necessary infrastructure, required in a post
            conflict situation, in addition to contributing to
            transitional safety nets for ex-combatants re-entering civil
            life. The Credit will complement the support provided by the
            European Union, the International Monetary Fund, and the
            British Department for International Development, and will
            be implemented parallel to the Community Reintegration and
            Rehabilitation Project. Regardless of possible risks, -
            deterioration of the political situation, governmental unity
            failure, and implementation delays due to capacity
            weaknesses - the economic recovery, envisaged to curb
            inflation, while maintaining a macroeconomic stability, far
            outweighs the risks.
